titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Hugh Anderson Moran papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Tanya Yule

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-09-25T12:22-0700

change.item: Revised to update encoding and add unitid by Elizabeth Phillips.
PUBLIC "-//Stanford University::Hoover Institution Archives//TEXT (US::CSt-H::::Hugh Anderson Moran Papers)//EN" "moranhu.sgm" converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.cdl.xsl (2004-09-16).

physdesc.extent: 5 manuscript boxes, 1 oversize box, 1 oversize folder

did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, clippings, maps, posters, and photographs relating to the Russian Civil War, political and economic conditions in Siberia and Manchuria, and relief work in Siberia and Manchuria, especially in the prisoner of war camps, during the Russian Civil War.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Hugh Anderson Moran papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1948.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Dr. Hugh Anderson Moran (1881-1977) graduated from Stanford University in 1905, and was the first athlete to receive the the prestigious Rhodes Scholarship. Moran was a member of the Delta Upsilon fraternity, president of the English Club, officer in the Young Men's Christian Association, and a member of the varsity track team.

Earning a doctorate in religion from Columbia University and Union Theological Seminary, Moran was ordained as a minister in the Presbyterian Church in 1908. He went on to serve as a Secretary of the International Committee of the Y.M.C.A. in China from 1909 to 1913. From 1916 to 1918, Moran was stationed in Vladivostok, Russia, in charge of prisoner of war relief in Siberia; he was also the special aide to Senator Elihu Root as part of the Special Diplomatic Mission in Russia in 1917.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, writings, clippings, maps, posters, and photographs relating to the Russian Civil War, political and economic conditions in Siberia and Manchuria, and relief work in Siberia and Manchuria, especially in the prisoner of war camps, during the Russian Civil War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters from 1916 to 1918 begin with Moran entering Harbin, and contain accounts and daily activities of his station in Vladivostok. Correspondents include Governor David R. Francis, Dr. John R. Mott, A. C. Harte, Esq., Senator Elihu Root, J. A. Caldwell, Russell M. Story, and various Y.M.C.A. personnel stationed in Russia. Correspondence from 1919 to 1931 includes follow up on Moran's accounts in Russia, his personal life, and materials used in research pertaining to the Russian Civil War.

did.unittitle: Receipts pertaining to prisoner of war supplies,
Reports and records pertaining to Y.M.C.A. secretaries working in Siberia,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains an organized chart created by Moran; data focuses on major events and conflicts starting May 12, 1917, and ending November 14, 1922.

did.unittitle: White Armies of Russia, by George Stewart,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains essays, letters, manuscript drafts, and reports that are written by Stewart and other contributors. Notes within the materials are provided by Moran.

did.unittitle: Transcript of Milikukov's speech in the Russian Duma,
"The position Kept by France and Great Britain toward Fight against Bolsheviks in Russia,"
Letters to Josef Stalin and Leon Trotsky,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains a letter from Colonel Siroboyarsky, a representative of Ataman Semenoff, detailing his experience on the front line as a White Russian soldier and discussing the conditions of the soldiers and the civilians; and fan letters to Stewart following the release of his book.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous papers pertaining to the Russian Civil War,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ink drawing of Russian soldier with horse in river.

did.unittitle: Open letter to the Provisional Russian government, from President Woodrow Wilson,
Bulletin regarding the American Relief Administration (A.R.A.),
List of members of the Social Soviet Government,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains propaganda leaflets and a poster by Dmitry Stakhievich Orlov (Дмитрий Стахиевич Орлов).

did.unittitle: Book fragments pertaining to leadership within the White Army,
Book fragments pertaining to the Russian Civil War,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most pages contain contextual annotations, and translations by Moran.

did.unittitle: Russian Armies in Exile, 1920 to 1923 (pamphlet translation),

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains full page rotogravures of Wrangel's troops (1920), and the Tsar's last photograph (1921) from the Chicago Sunday Tribune.

did.unittitle: Articles pertaining to the Soviet Union,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes lithographs of Russian landmarks, a copy of a letter from Dr. Chapman from Reverend Buchak regarding missionary work in Molodiatyn (1925), a report on the evangelical movement in Ukraine from the European Central Bureau for Church Relief Work (1927), and various clippings pertaining to religion in Ukraine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains various Russian currency, including Tsar Nicholas II currency stamps (1915-1916), and Red and White Army currency.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of the photographs contain annotations from Moran, or are series photographs from Underwood and Underwood.

did.unittitle: Portrait of 12 year old Czech soldier,
Students from the University of Tonsk going back to Garda to relieve the Czechs,
Russian frontier between Siberia and Mongolia, portrait of White Army soldier,
The army of the new provisional government at Harbin, Manchuria,
Grandmother of the revolution, Breshkovskaya, in her car at Vladivstok,
Train in which Tsar Nicholas II abdicated,
Convicts from the prison in Tschita taking part in Labor Day parade,
Senator Root, General Scott, Dr. Mott,
Japanese officers visiting Russian athletic sports held at Harbin, by American Y.M.C.A.,
Party of Americans escaping by way of Blagovestchensk,
Morgan Palmer with American relief workers escaping from Siberia,
Graves of German soldiers in Russian Poland,
Russians waiting in a line for tea,
Military procession going to church to pray for victory,
Czech soldier who threw a hand grenade at Bolshevik headquarters,
Convicts from the prison in Tschita taking part in Labor Day parade,
Kerensky as head of provisional government,
Carvings by a German soldier in Siberia,
Ukrainian army prepares to fight Bolsheviks,
Admiral Kolchak's troops in the UFA,
Trotsky and Lenin speaking in Red Square,
